content.title: The Energy Access Landscape
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

The global energy landscape is marked by a profound disparity in access to energy services, chiefly manifested between regions, but also between urban and rural areas, formal and informal settlements, connected or isolated communities, higher and lower incomes communities, and among those in fragile contexts. This disparity is often referred to as the 'Global Energy Gap' - or 'Global Energy Divide'. In this lesson, we provide an overview of the key characteristics and statistics of these multiple divides.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy access for informal settlements
concepts.body: Energy access for informal settlements refers to the availability and affordability of reliable energy services, such as electricity and clean cooking fuels, for residents living in unplanned or informal housing areas, ensuring they can meet their basic energy needs and improve their quality of life.

concepts.title: energy in crisis settings
concepts.body: Energy in crisis settings refers to the provision and management of energy resources in areas affected by emergencies, such as natural disasters, armed conflicts, or humanitarian crises, where access to reliable energy is critical for survival, recovery, and rebuilding efforts.

concepts.title: global energy gap
concepts.body: The global energy gap refers to the disparity between the world's energy demand and the available energy supply, highlighting the need for increased energy production and sustainable solutions to meet future energy needs.

content.text: The 'Global Energy Gap'

The Global Energy Access Gap refers to the stark disparity between regions, countries, or communities in accessing reliable, affordable, and modern energy services. This divide reinforces economic inequality, restricts development opportunities, and worsens poverty. The gap is composed of cumulative layers that further entrench inequalities, making energy access a deeply structural challenge. With the added pressures of climate change, these disparities will only intensify if not swiftly addressed. Each layer presents unique characteristics, requiring tailored solutions to meet the distinct needs and contexts of different regions and communities.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Regions with Quasi-Universal Access

content.text: Part 1 Overview

In some regions of the world, energy access challenges are a thing of the past. These countries have achieved near-universal access to both electricity and clean cooking. This section highlights the status and key characteristics of high-access regions, showing what is possible with sustained investment and policy support.

High-income regions such as Northern America, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, and much of East Asia have achieved near-universal access to both electricity and clean cooking. As of 2022, the global electricity access rate reached 91%, and in high-income countries, access typically exceeds 99% for both electricity and clean fuels (IEA., 2024). In Europe and Central Asia, for example, the electricity access rate was virtually 100%, while the clean cooking access rate stood at 98%. Similarly, countries like Japan and South Korea have universal energy access, thanks to strong infrastructure, supportive regulatory frameworks, and robust financial systems.

In China, electricity access is nearly universal, and the country has made remarkable progress in clean cooking. Between 2010 and 2022, China contributed to 28% of the global increase in clean cooking access. The country’s access rate to clean fuels and technologies reached over 90% by 2022, thanks to large-scale government programs promoting LPG and electricity-based cooking. In Latin America and the Caribbean, the electricity access rate reached 98.4% in 2022, while clean cooking access stood at 88%, with countries like Brazil, Chile, and Costa Rica nearing 100% in both metrics. Urban areas in these regions show the highest access rates. In urban Latin America, for example, electricity access exceeds 99%, while clean cooking access surpasses 95%. The widespread use of LPG and electricity in cooking, coupled with high income levels and urban density, has facilitated these gains.

The experience of these regions highlights the importance of strong institutional capacity, integrated planning, and stable financial support. Furthermore, universal access in these regions is supported by targeted subsidies for vulnerable populations, which ensures that energy remains affordable for all. In high-income countries, energy access has progressed hand in hand with relative policy stability, infrastructure resilience, and widespread consumer trust in public services.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | A
content.title: A: Countries on a Fast Track to Energy Access

content.text: Overview

In contrast to regions where universal access has been achieved, some countries have made exceptional progress in recent years. This section focuses on those "rapid progress" regions where access to electricity and clean cooking is expanding rapidly due to strong policies, investment, and innovation.

Several low- and middle-income countries have made significant progress in expanding electricity and clean cooking access over the past decade. India, for instance, accounted for 42% of the global progress in clean cooking access between 2010 and 2022. India’s clean cooking access rate increased from 30% in 2010 to 75% in 2022. The country also achieved nearly universal electricity access, with less than 1% of its population without power in 2022. Bangladesh also made significant strides, increasing electricity access from 47% in 2000 to nearly 100% by 2022. Its clean cooking access rate, however, remains low at 46%, highlighting a need for further investment in cooking transitions. Indonesia, represent another story of progress with an increase in clean cooking access rate from 60% in 2010 to 83% in 2022, contributing 10% of the global gain in this area. Pakistan improved from 50% to 70% in clean cooking access, representing 3% of global progress.

In Africa, Rwanda and Kenya have achieved significant gains in electrification. Rwanda increased electricity access from 9% in 2010 to 68% in 2022, while Kenya moved from 28% to 76% over the same period. However, both countries continue to struggle with clean cooking, with access rates below 30%. The average annual increase in electrification globally was 0.77 percentage points between 2010 and 2020, but slowed to 0.43 percentage points between 2020 and 2022. In contrast, countries like India and Bangladesh had strong momentum, with 40.1 million new connections annually in South Asia during 2020–2022. These examples show that political will, coordinated investment, and decentralized energy solutions can catalyze rapid improvements.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | B
content.title: B: Regions Struggling with Energy Access

content.text: Overview

While some regions are rapidly progressing toward universal energy access, others are falling behind. This section highlights areas where the majority of people still lack basic energy services, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa and fragile states. Some of these regions face persistent barriers such as political instability, lack og access to financing, and weak institutions.

Sub-Saharan Africa remains the region most significantly lagging behind on energy access. In 2022, only 48% of the population had access to electricity, and just 18% had access to clean cooking fuels and technologies. This means around 600 million people in the region still lacked electricity, and over 923 million were dependent on traditional biomass, charcoal, or kerosene for cooking. The region now accounts for 83% of the global electricity access deficit, up from 50% in 2010. Annual population growth in Sub-Saharan Africa, around 28.7 million people per year, is nearly equal to the annual increase in electricity access, which was 31.1 million between 2020 and 2022. This parity slows overall progress and highlights the need for faster electrification. Among the 20 countries with the largest energy access deficits, 18 are in Sub-Saharan Africa, with Nigeria (86 million), Democratic Republic of Congo (78 million), and Ethiopia (55 million) with the highest number of people lacking access, due notably to their large population.

Clean cooking access is also stagnant in Sub-Saharan Africa. Of the 20 countries with the largest clean cooking access deficits, 8 had access rates below 10% in 2022. These include Ethiopia, Madagascar, Mozambique, Niger, and Uganda. Projections show that over 1 billion people in the region could still be without clean cooking by 2030 if current trends persist. Progress is also limited in fragile and conflict-affected settings. In these contexts, access to electricity was 57% in 2022, up from 46% in 2010. However, the absolute number of people without access increased slightly from 427 million in 2020 to 429 million in 2022 due to rapid population growth, limited infrastructure development as well as the social and economic consequences of the COVID 19 pandemic. Least developed countries also saw a stagnation in progress, with access around 57%

content.title: Part 2: Further Layers of Polarization and Regional Specificities

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A: The Urban - Rural Divide

content.text: Overview

The energy divide is clear to see between urban and rural areas around the world. While urban centers generally benefit from established infrastructure, many rural communities remain underserved. This section explores the urban - rural energy access gap. We will examine the primary factors driving these inequalities and discuss current trends and key element to consider to promote universal access to sustainable energy.
The energy divide is clear to see between urban and rural areas around the world. Click on each image below to reveal the differences between urban vs. rural energy access
Urban areas

Usually have well-established electricity grids, enabling residents to access a continuous and stable power supply. Provide greater variety of energy services, such as heating, cooling, and cooking. Have readily available energy due to the concentration of infrastructure and service providers. The prevalence of modern energy solutions in urban settings contributes to improved living standards, facilitates economic activities, and supports the overall dynamism of urban life. However, there are important exceptions - as outlined in the next section.
Rural areas (especially in developing countries)

Often face costlier and more complex energy infrastructure development due to low population density and challenging geography, leading to limited access and higher connection costs. Provide fewer diverse energy options, as immature renewable energy markets and ecosystems restrict affordable and sustainable solutions. Often rely on traditional and inefficient energy sources, such as biomass, kerosene, or open fires, for basic needs like cooking and heating. The lack of electricity infrastructure in rural areas hampers not only domestic activities but also limits opportunities for education, healthcare, and economic development.

Urbanization rates are accelerating worldwide, further stressing energy access in cities. With the global population reaching 8 billion in November 2022, more than half (55%) now live in urban areas—a number projected to rise to 70% by 2050. Much of this urban growth occurs in small cities and intermediate towns, compounding existing inequalities and urban poverty (UNSTATS, 2023). Click on any year of the chart below to see the number of urban or rural people per given year, or click the play button to watch how their growth has changed between 1960 and 2021
55% of global population live in urban areas, consuming 2/3 of the world’s energy

As cities expand, so does their energy consumption. Urban areas consume two-thirds of the world's energy (UNEP, 2021), demanding an uninterrupted supply to meet the needs of residents. Rapid urbanization, aging electricity grids, and unplanned expansions can lead to inefficiencies, blackouts, and higher costs. Additionally, socioeconomic inequalities mean that modern energy services are often unaffordable for the most vulnerable populations. Greater efforts are needed to ensure that all urban residents benefit from sustainable and inclusive energy solutions.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | B
content.title: B: Informal Settlements and Underserved Neighborhoods

content.text: Informal settlements or slums (ISs) are typically defined as densely populated areas characterized by inadequate housing and limited access to essential services such as clean water, sanitation, and electricity. Although these challenges are not exclusive to ISs, they are more prevalent and acute in such settings. The lack of formal infrastructure in ISs often results in heightened vulnerability to hazards, limited mobility, poor waste management, and exposure to health and safety risks, making these issues not only more common but also more critical than in other urban areas. These neighborhoods often emerge without formal planning and lack legal recognition, which exacerbates the challenges residents face regarding infrastructure, health, and economic opportunities. Over 1.1 billion people live in ISs globally (WEF, 2023) and rapid urbanization projects that number could double in the next 30 years, particularly in developing regions (Kuffer et. al., 2019). In Sub-Saharan Africa, more than half of the urban population lives currently lives in in ISs.
1.1 billion people

Click on any country in the interactive map below to see the percentage of urban population living in ISs around the world as of 2020, or click the play button to see change in slum populations from 2002 to 2020 (Source Our World in Data, 2020).

The figure below illustrates the many forms that energy access can take in ISs - both formal or informal, with payments to landlords, the utility or electricity reseller, and diverse connection types. Many such connection types - such as as direct line tapping (Type C), meter bypasses (Type D), and using extension cords strung precariously (Type E) pose immediate safety hazards

Understanding the economic realities that push residents towards informal connections, along with the social dynamics within these communities, is crucial to improving energy access in ISs. Governments, the private sector, and communities can all take steps toward improving this access. The starting point is recognizing informal settlements as a symptom of social inequality, not a crime. Historically, enforcement actions have bred distrust between utilities and ISs, hindering cooperation. Collaboration is key to improving services. Utilities must shift from punishment to partnership, engaging the informal electricity market to create a win-win situation. Legal recognition of ISs is also essential to formalize access to safer, regulated electricity.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | C
content.title: C: Last-Mile and Isolated Populations

content.text: Last-mile communities are the hardest-to-reach populations and face mounting challenges in accessing energy. Typically located in remote, low-density rural areas, extending traditional grids to these regions is economically unfeasible and logistically complex. These remote communities usually depend on minimal or subsistence economic activity, face physical barriers to accessibility, and are considerably distant from external markets. In this context, infrastructure costs are high, and limited access to financial resources restricts the adoption of off-grid solutions. Mountain areas, where 1.05 billion people lived in 2015 (14% of the global population), are a prominent example. Population density decreases with altitude, and communities at higher elevations experience harsher weather, heightening energy needs for cooking, space heating, and water heating.

Protected areas are rapidly expanding and projected to cover 30% of land and sea by 2030. (Mouillot et al., 2024). These territories may face more restrictive regulations, which can limit infrastructure development and pose regulatory barriers to electrification projects. In some regions, migration to urban areas has reshaped local demographics making these remote communities more vulnerable. Trends include the “feminization” of agriculture, where men migrate for work while women maintain rural livelihoods (CGIAR, 2021).
Example

In Koh Kantheay, Cambodia, UNDP supported a microgrid project to provide isolated communities with reliable energy access. This model, based on public-private-community partnerships, included a 70% public subsidy for initial infrastructure setup and a 30% contribution from private energy entrepreneurs, who oversee grid operations. This project demonstrates the potential of solar microgrids to deliver sustainable energy access to remote communities, fostering public-private partnerships and reducing investment risk (UNDP Cambodia, 2023). Developing sustainable off-grid energy solutions in last-mile areas , like solar microgrid, presented in the case study above, demands tailored technical support and long-term financing mechanisms. These instruments will be presented in more details in the following modules.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | D
content.title: D: Small Island Developing States (SIDS)

content.text: Small island developing states (SIDS) are a group of 57 island nations with a combined population of approximately 65 million. Due to their remote geographical locations, these populations face distinct social, economic, and environmental challenges along with unique energy access difficulties. As of 2021, the average electricity access rate in SIDS was around 91%, and access to clean cooking stood at 58%, significantly below the global average of 74% (UNDP., 2025). These averages, however, mask important disparities between and within countries. Geographic isolation, small markets, and reliance on imported fossil fuels make energy in SIDS expensive and volatile. Fossil fuels still make up around 75% of the electricity mix in SIDS, with approximately 60% of them importing over 90% of their fossil fuel needs . This leads to high energy costs, up to four times higher than in continental regions, with frequent supply disruptions and high public subsidies. For instance, fossil fuel subsidies reached 8% of GDP in Suriname and 3.7% in Timor-Leste, severely straining public finances that could be directed toward clean energy investments. While some SIDS like Singapore, Barbados, and the Maldives have achieved near-universal access, others face major deficits. In Papua New Guinea, only 19% of the population had access to electricity in 2022., while Vanuatu’s electricity access rate stood at 70%, and 37.4% in Guinea-Bissau. The rural-urban divide is stark, with only 1.2% of rural residents having electricity access in Haiti compared to 79.9% in urban areas, while in Kiribati rural clean cooking access is 2% versus 20% in urban areas.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | E
content.title: E: Fragile and conflict contexts

content.text: Refugee Camps and Forcibly Displaced Populations

At mid-2024, the number of people forced to flee conflict, violence, human rights violations, and persecution exceeded 122 million (UNHCR, 2024). More than 6.6 million people live in refugee camps and more than 94% of households in camps lack access to electricity, while while 81% rely on firewood or charcoal for cooking. This reliance exacerbates environmental degradation, increases health risks, and impacts the safety of vulnerable populations, particularly women and children. Refugee camps are frequently located in remote areas, where limited infrastructure and high logistics costs further complicate the provision of energy. To address this, humanitarian agencies spend over $108 million annually on diesel fuel, resulting in over 194,000 tons of CO₂ emissions (UNEP, 2023) (UN Refugees, 2021) Refugee camps face acute energy needs due to dense populations and limited infrastructure. Decentralized renewable energy systems, such as solar mini-grids, are emerging as effective alternatives. These systems are faster to deploy and less capital-intensive than centralized grids, making them more adaptable to remote and temporary camp settings.
Environmental hazards, crisis and conflict settings

Major crises across the globe, spanning from Afghanistan to Congo, Haiti, Palestine, Ukraine, Sudan, Yemen, and beyond, have inflicted significant, sometimes generational setbacks to development progress, leaving people in these contexts facing an increasingly uncertain future. Approximately 15 percent of the world’s total population – roughly 1.2 billion people – reside in conflict-affected areas (UNDP, 2022), while disaster losses have sharply risen, impacting 4.2 billion individuals over the past two decades (UNDRR, 2020). Example: The impact of energy loss is starkly illustrated by nighttime images of areas hit by disasters or conflict, such as power outages following Cyclone Fani or widespread blackouts during the Ukraine war, showing the devastating impact of disrupted energy access in these fragile settings.

Environmental hazards, crises, and conflict settings often result in severe energy infrastructure damage or complete destruction, making reliable energy access scarce. Centralized energy infrastructure is highly vulnerable to damage due to its reliance on long transmission lines, single points of failure, and limited flexibility in the face of shocks. This makes decentralized energy solutions essential for resilience. Distributed energy systems, such as solar-powered mini-grids, can quickly restore power to critical facilities, including health clinics and water systems. Given their smaller size, they are also less apt to be disrupted by military events in conflict prone regions. Mobile renewable energy units have also proven effective in providing immediate energy solutions during crises.

Resilient energy infrastructure plays a crucial role in post-crisis recovery. The UNDP Sustainable Energy Hub (SEH) defines energy resilience in fragile contexts as the ability of individuals, communities, and systems to withstand and recover from shocks and stresses related to energy supply, demand, and access. For instance, recovery plans can include tailored strategies for sustainable and resilient energy integration, such as financing mechanisms to de-risk investments and incentivize private sector participation to address funding shortages. The intersection of the climate crisis and fragility underscores the need for long-term resilience planning. For example, integrating renewable energy into health systems during crises, as demonstrated in past outbreaks like COVID-19, has shown that sustainable energy can simultaneously address immediate needs and create pathways for green recovery. Energy access in fragile and conflict contexts requires targeted interventions that combine immediate solutions with long-term sustainable strategies. Decentralized renewable energy systems—such as solar home systems, mini-grids, solar-powered water pumps, and portable clean energy units—offer adaptable and rapidly deployable solutions that can operate independently of vulnerable central grids. These systems can be well-suited for remote or insecure areas where infrastructure is damaged or non-existent. By scaling such technologies, fostering innovative financing mechanisms, and embedding energy resilience into broader recovery and development strategies, it is possible to mitigate the impacts of crises and ensure more reliable support for vulnerable populations.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: The global energy divide reflects significant regional disparities. This inequality is compounded by geographic factors, where rural and last-mile communities remain largely off-grid, and even within urban areas, informal settlements and underserved neighborhoods experience inconsistent and often unsafe energy sources.

In refugee camps, disaster zones, and conflict-affected settings, energy access becomes critical yet precarious, often relegated to short-term solutions that lack sustainability. These contexts reveal a heightened need for resilient, quickly deployable energy systems that support basic services while protecting health and safety, emphasizing the vulnerability of displaced populations and fragile areas.

Effective energy access solutions must be tailored to specific local needs and cultural contexts, whether for Indigenous communities, isolated last-mile regions, or informal urban settlements. Addressing these varied contexts requires flexible, inclusive approaches that incorporate community engagement, recognize cultural values, and offer innovative, sustainable solutions suited to each environment.
